sentences.sentence: The purposes and principles embedded in the United Nations Charter are not a matter of convenience.
And they exist precisely to address any grievance - whatever it may be.

One year ago, I sat in this Council and urged: “In the name of humanity do not allow to start in Europe what could be the worst war since the beginning of the century, with consequences not only devastating for Ukraine, not only tragic for the Russian Federation, but with an impact we cannot even foresee in relation to the consequences for the global economy.” I said then that we must give peace a chance.
The Russian invasion of Ukraine is a blatant violation of the United Nations Charter and international law.
Attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure have caused many casualties and terrible suffering.
The Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights has documented dozens of cases of conflict-related sexual violence against men, women and girls.

Serious violations of international humanitarian and human rights law against prisoners of war - and hundreds of cases of enforced disappearances and arbitrary detentions of civilians - were also documented.
Life is a living hell for the people of Ukraine.
An estimated 17.6 million people ᅳ nearly 40 per cent of the population of Ukraine ᅳ require humanitarian assistance and protection.
The crisis has erased 30 per cent of pre-war jobs.
The World Food Programme estimates that nearly 40 per cent of Ukrainians are unable to afford or access enough food.
The war has sparked a displacement crisis not seen in Europe in decades.
More than 8 million Ukrainian refugees have been recorded across Europe, in addition to an estimated 5.4 million people who have been internally displaced.
More than half of all Ukrainian children have been forced from their homes - with

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.

text: The purposes and principles embedded in the United Nations Charter are not a matter of convenience. And they exist precisely to address any grievance – whatever it may be. One year ago, I sat in this Council and urged: “In the name of humanity do not allow to start in Europe what could be the worst war since the beginning of the century, with consequences not only devastating for Ukraine, not only tragic for the Russian Federation, but with an impact we cannot even foresee in relation to the consequences for the global economy.” I said then that we must give peace a chance. The Russian invasion of Ukraine is a blatant violation of the United Nations Charter and international law. Attacks on civilians and civilian infrastructure have caused many casualties and terrible suffering. The Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights has documented dozens of cases of conflict-related sexual violence against men, women and girls. Serious violations of international humanitarian and human rights law against prisoners of war – and hundreds of cases of enforced disappearances and arbitrary detentions of civilians – were also documented. Life is a living hell for the people of Ukraine. An estimated 17.6 million people — nearly 40 per cent of the population of Ukraine — require humanitarian assistance and protection. The crisis has erased 30 per cent of pre-war jobs. The World Food Programme estimates that nearly 40 per cent of Ukrainians are unable to afford or access enough food. The war has sparked a displacement crisis not seen in Europe in decades. More than 8 million Ukrainian refugees have been recorded across Europe, in addition to an estimated 5.4 million people who have been internally displaced.
